> I have always found the difference between ERROR and
> FAILURE confusing and I bet that except for JUnit experts
> such as yourself, nobody can really explain it.

From the JUnit cookbook:

"In the case of an unsuccessful test JUnit reports the
failed tests in a list at the bottom. JUnit distinguishes
between failures and errors. A failure is anticipated and
checked for with assertions. Errors are unanticipated
problems like an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException. The
following figure shows an example of a failed test."

It doesn't get much clear than that... now, I know that
people will rather post questions to a mailing list than
read the doco, but at least it is in there.

> Assuming that it's important to know whether a test failed
> because of an assert of an unexpected exception (a dubious
> proposition in the first place since when a test fails,
> you are going to check out the stack trace anyway and find
> out exactly where it failed), it would certainly have been
> better to name them differently.

The point of the difference, Cedric, is that when you come
in and find that 101 tests didn't pass, you should start
with the failing tests before going on to the error tests.

The same goes if you come in and find that 101 tests didn't
pass because 100 were skipped - you'd presumably start with
the failing one first. :)

Yes, these are habits to develop, but they aren't hard
habits to develop.

Robert.
